comment_1: I think this a melancholy tune about a girl who loves a guy who isn't that nice to her.  She tries to please him wearing his favourite dress and perfume.  "whistling my name" suggest he calls to her and she runs to him like a dog to his master.  They lyrics "Watching me get undressed Take that body downtown" suggest at a darkness.  "They say that the world was built for two Only worth living if somebody is loving you" suggest that she thinks she will only be happy if she is with someone.  The reference to video games might mean he plays her like she is a game or it might be that she less important to him than video games.
comment_2:
I'm going to give my opinion on video games, and I've probably listened to the song over a hundred times. When the song first came out I remember reading an interview or article where Lana explains how it's about two people. One guy she's actually currently in a relationship with. The other is an old relationship that she's obviously still thinking about the guy, and wishing things had turned out differently. She went onto say that the verses are about how it actually was with the one guy and then the chorus is how she actually wished it had been with the previous relationship. From the lyrics you can grasp that the current relationship is kind of becoming tedious. But if you actually pay attention to the lyrics you will pick up that she uses two different possessive adjectives "his" and "your". With that in mind if you look at the lyrics it makes sense because even though she's with one guy everything she's doing subconsciously is for the other. 



Swinging in the backyard
Pull up in your fast car whistling my name 
Open up a beer
And you say get over here and play a video game
(This is what actually happened.. "your")

I'm in his favorite sun dress 
Watching me get undressed take that body downtown
(She's in his, meaning the other guys favorite sundress)

I say you the bestest
Lean in for a big kiss put his favorite perfume on
(She says he's the best and is putting on a facade of total happiness, yet she still puts the other guys favorite perfume on)

Like previously stated the chorus is about the old relationship and how she wished it had been. It correlates with how she referenced it in the verses, how she's doing things for the other guy even though she's in a relationship with the one. She's putting on his favorite sundress and perfume. 

It's you, it's you, it's all for you
Everything I do
I tell you all the time
Heaven is a place on earth with you
Tell me all the things you want to do
I heard that you like the bad girls honey, is that true?
It's better than I ever even knew
They say that the world was built for two
Only worth living if somebody is loving you
Baby now you do

Even though she's in one relationship, she's still doing everything for the old one.

According to an article posted on the website Dazed Digital:

At the same time, she was dealing with the fallout from two broken relationships, so she took Parkerâs template and wrote down what was on her mind.

âThe verse was about the way things were with one person, and the chorus was the way that I wished things had really been with another person, who I thought about for a long time,â she says, breaking into an acapella of the song. ââSwinging in the backyard, pull up in your fast car, whistling my nameâ. That was what happened, you know? Heâd come home and Iâd see him. But then the chorus, âHeaven is a place on earth with you, tell me all the things you wanna doâ wasnât like that. That was the way that I wished it was â the melody sounds so compelling and heavenly because I wanted it to be that way. The verse is more matter-of-fact because thatâs how it was. Itâs a mix of memories and the way I wished it could have been. Just because things happened a certain way doesnât mean that thatâs the way that they are. It really is what you choose to think about. Bad things happen every day but youâre not going to be any happier thinking about them. So I donât think about them. I donât have that luxury any more. Some people say that âVideo Gamesâ stops them in their tracks; itâs that kind of song. Itâs just really sad."
comment_4:
According to Lana herself:
"Itâs just about this guy I had been seeing and the way our relationship was at the time. It was a time in my life when I had let go of my own personal career ambitions and just enjoyed being with him at home when heâd come home from work and play video games. Iâd write while Iâd watch him. I think when I wrote that song I was just reflecting on the sweetness of it, but also the fact that there was something else I was longing for at the same time. Thematically, it feels personal to me. I wouldnât have thought that that was the song that people responded to. That is why I get so emotional and happy when I sing it. Because it is a gift for someone like me. Melodically and thematically, Video Games is a perfect representation of me."
comment_5:
I'm kind of saddened by all these dark/negative interpretations... I was feeling a melancholic happiness, but not emotional abuse. The song is kind of ruined for me now...

I was feeling a melancholy towards a simple happiness. When putting on his favorite dress made her feel like a million dollars, and happiness was in the little things; hanging out together, having fun with friends. When at the end of the day, happiness was simple, and now she has bigger worries.

I could relate to it because me and my boyfriend have a lot of financial struggle at the moment, but still happiness seems such a strong and simple thing when we play video games together or have drinks with our wonderful friends and family. That dispite the sorrows we carry, maling ourselves and each other happy together with little things is still possible. We can't buy new clothes but when I put on that dress we both love I still feel like the richest woman on earth.

I guess people hear what they can relate to. No doubt I would have heard more sadness in it two years ago when I was still involved with an emotionally abusive guy. It's all about where your own mind is at, too. I just hear "heaven is a place on earth with you" above all other insinuations.

comment_10:
I like a lot of what people are saying here. I've been researching opinions and thoughts on her for days now. I find her two tunes "video games" and "born to die" entirely intoxicating. However I dont find any of their immense sadness or eerieness in the album itself though which is a bit lacklustre.
Anyway I think it goes deeper than people have been saying. Postmodern is a problematic term to ascribe but I think in her case it is absolutely appropriate. "Video Games" isn't that she simply watches a man play video games, or that he films her having sex etc Video Games are the symbol or lens with which she view her whole status as a woman and a human being in the 21st century. Everything is playing a part, life is characterised by reproduction of image, cliche and unoriginality, to use Baudrillard's phrase it is a "loss of the real", all is surface, all is texture: she moves, lives, loves in a video. Her collage of american film, film music, american country music, combine with a string of cliches that make up her lyrics "it's all for you" "heaven is a place on earth" "hold me in your big arms" to form an overwhelming, suffocating sense of unreality.

The immense sadness in these two songs isn't so much emotional sadness but is a profound weariness. Much art and music has grown tired and film and video has come so close to life that relationships and emotions can feel just as mechanical. 

She is a huge Kurt Cobain fan apparently. Play the first 10 seconds of Video Games, then first ten seconds of Nirvana's Plateau. The similarity is striking. Both have a similar vibe. Moreover I think the image of the Plateau is a nice way of understanding her world-view in these two songs:  life is surface, controlled, boundrary-defined, static, stagnant and unchanging.
comment_11: I think she's simply saying that she sacrifices her best interests to a man in the name of love. She's playing life like a surrealistic adventure game to keep her relationship alive.

comment_14:
Wow, I've had a really different interpretation of this song. Obviously my interpretation does not match up with Lana's explanation or most of the interpretations posted here. But the text is pretty versatile and can be interpreted several ways, so I thought I'd post my take on it (even though it is not the "correct" interpretation - more just a commentary on some of the (rather dark) imagery my mind conjures up when I hear this song. Here goes:


---- "CHAPTER ONE" ----
Swinging in the backyard
Pull up in your fast car whistling my name
Open up a beer
And you say get over here and play a video game

INTERPRETATION:
Childhood memories. A young girl is playing in the backyard, on a swing set. Someone - in my mind a stepfather - drives up, lures the child inside the house with the promise of entertainment (play a video game) but in fact his intentions are more sinister.

Cleverly, this segues into the next segment, where the girl in the fist chapter has grown up, and now has a child of her own:


--- "CHAPTER TWO"---
I'm in his favorite sun dress
Watching me get undressed
take that body downtown
I say you the bestest
Lean in for a big kiss put his favorite perfume on
Go play your video game

INTERPRETATION:
A mother has had enjoyed a sunny afternoon with her child (presumably a boy) who is watching as the mother gets ready for work, which is to "take that body downtown": She is a prostitute, preparing to meet a particular client. She gives a "big kiss" for goodbye, then asks the child to stay here, play your videogames - I'll be home late.

--- CHORUS ---
It's you, it's you, it's all for you
Everything I do
I tell you all the time
Heaven is a place on earth with you

INTERPRETATION:
She is singing to the child, everything she does is for her child, everything she has to put up with is worth it for the time the two of them has together.

--- CHAPTER  THREE ---
Tell me all the things you want to do
I heard that you like the bad girls honey, is that true?
It's better than I ever even knew

INTERPRETATION:
She's talking to a client now.
As she is getting busy, her mind drifts to other, happier things; her child and the live they share. The line "It's better than I ever even knew", could both be a (dishonest) line delivered to her client, but it could also be an earnest thought sent to her child, who is playing video games back home. In the next two lines her thoughts are more clearly aimed at the child:

---
They say that the world was built for two
Only worth living if somebody is loving you
Baby now you do

--- CHAPTER FOUR---:
Singing in the old bars
Swinging with the old stars
Living for the fame

Kissing in the blue dark
Playing pool and wild darts
Video games

INTERPRETATION:
She's out working - or maybe she's just hanging out in a bar, getting drunk. "Swinging" is a particularily apt choice of words - it was also used in the first line of the song - but most likely in a different meaning here. She passes the time playing pool. Waiting for the next client is like wild darts, the outcome is unknown and random. 

She is distant and disconnected. To her, this part of her life it's like  playing a video game: she is  controlling a character (herself) doing strange things.

She meets a client, she is drunk and possibly a drugged.
They have "relations":

---
He holds me in his big arms
Drunk and I am seeing stars
---

Again, her mind wanders to her "happy place":

---
This is all I think of
Watching all our friends fall
In and out of Old Paul's
This is my idea of fun
Playing video games

---
INTERPRETATION:
She's thinking of happier times, calling up happy memories,
The song then goes into repetitions of the chorus:
It's you, it's you, it's all for you (etc.)

At his point, the song opens up to several possible interpretations of what is going on in the present or future:
Maybe she's escaping to her happy place as the client is becoming more demanding/active - he's strong, she's "seeng stars" - often a result of being beaten/hit in the head. Is he violent?
Maybe her lifestyle is bringing her into a vicious cycle; she looses custody and start doing more drugs, more booze, becoming less and less critical of what clients she picks up in order to sustain her substance abuse, which is her gateway to her "happy place" where she deams of her times with child (interspersed by references to "bad girls", presumably herself).
Maybe she, instead, does strike up a more lasting relationship with one of her clients, bringing one into her family, as her child needs a father. One day in the future, this new stepfather might pull up in his fast car as the child is swinging in the back yard. 'COme here', the stepfather says to the playing child as he opens a can of beer, 'let's go into the hous and play some video games'.

Like I said: Probably not what Lana intended at all.

comment_18:
Um actually, to a article she EXPLAINS what the song is meant to mean,

She sings to the joy of pleasing her man, with the small details meaning everything ("I'm in his favorite sundress"). Just as Del Rey's image recalls an older generation, "Video Games" has her framing love in an older, traditional sense, with her man pulling up "in [your] fast car, whistling my name." The slight modern twist is he's drinking beer and playing a video game instead of working on a failing engine, but it's all the same. It's not the sexiest topic (Destiny's Child's "Cater 2 U" hit the "Indepedent" women with some backlash) but "Video Games" refuses to shy away from a timeless truth: There is still pleasure to be had in serving the person you love.

comment_21: I realize that Lana casually wrote this song about her experience in one of her relationships but I think the song accurately describes a power struggle between any two people in any kind of relationship. Whenever a human being allows themselves to metaphorically place another as a supreme being, this automatically gives this person a feeling of superiority. The "Hierarchy of needs" becomes compromised and the interaction between two people become unbalanced. This is where the ideal of equality lessens and the ball starts bouncing on one end of the court. However, experiences and circumstances change overtime and the roles can easily become reversed. In a romantic relationship, peoples priorities and actions towards others become muddled and video games become more important then the real challenge and reward of the love and affection between two people.
comment_22:
My father listened to this song a lot, trying to get down the meaning and he came up with an idea which I think fits perfectly. The song is about Lana trying to be the perfect girlfriend for a guy who just isn't worth it and won't treat her right.

First verse: 'Whistling my name', treats her like a dog or an accessory. 

'In his favourite sundress'- trying to do everything to please him, repeated with the favourite perfume. 
'Watching me get undressed'- a sense of alienation from herself, seeing herself as an object, which is how he sees her. 

'Open up a beer..play a video game'- he is the archetypal tough guy who essentially ignores her. 

'I say you the bestest, lean in for a big kiss'- she builds up his ego by giving him an unreal picture of himself. She tries to please by giving herself away. 

CHORUS- she admits every little thing she does is for him. She tries to live up to his sexual fantasies with the teasing lyric, 'I hear you like the bad girls' and tacks on the endearment 'honey', the tone of the line suggesting she is trying to be turned on by his preferences. She recites cliche and over the top things about their relationship and tries to justify her behaviour by suggesting love is the be all and end all- 'only worth living if somebody is loving you'.

'Baby now you do' could suggest she has come to her senses and left, and he loves her now he knows what he has lost. 

The second verse shows her trying to fit in with his lifestyle- 'pool and wild darts' being more stereotypical ideas of male activity. The bar is noisy and devoid of the intimacy she seems to crave- 'living for the fame' 'watching all our friends fall'. 

Again, her response to him is over the top- there is no real romanticism behind 'holds me in his big arms/drunk and I am seeing stars'- she is acting like an object for him to protect and the lifestyle has run away with her. Even the line 'this is my idea of fun' comes across as her reassuring herself in a defeatist manner.

Mostly the giveaway here is her tone- the songs sounds like it is in a minor key and all the romantic sentiments are sung in a low register with little change in tone, suggesting her depression and real feelings. The standout change is in 'honey, is that true?' where Lana sings in a higher register, as though pretending to be a Marilyn style femme fatale. 

Not my idea, but I think this interpretation fits the best of the others I've heard i.e. that it was about child grooming. Lana herself supposedly said it was about an old boyfriend.
comment_23:
Am I the only one who didn't initially think of this song as being sad and about a bad relationship? I can definitely see everybody's interpretations of it being true, however, I felt like this song was more about being inlove and enjoying all the simple things in a relationship. Being young - getting drunk together - just hanging out with friends doing pointless, ridiculous things that might seem lame to outside people, but are actually really good, funny times where you have to "be there to understand" just how funny and fun everything was. Maybe she repeatedly refers to video games because that's the key thing that winds down their day. They sit on the couch and play video games into the night and he includes her into this, aka, he let's her into his world. 

Anyways, that's why interpretations of songs are fun. There are endless interpretations.
comment_24: I don't see anything sinister in this song. I see melancholy and lament. Lana herself said this song was about a guy she was with, yet their life together became uninteresting and they eventually broke up. What happens after "they lived happily ever after?" That's what this song explores. There was a contentment between the two, but she longed for some kind of passion from him, to become something greater, for example, the line, "watching all our friends/in and out of Old Paul's" - everyone else is getting married, yet their is no direction for him. She truly loves him, yet he clearly doesn't feel the same way. Of course this is unrequited love. Love is one of the most special experiences, she invests so much into getting his attention, yet he'd rather just play video games. To him, love is just a video game, you can stop by for a bit, have fun, and stop whenever you want to do something else; there is no real commitment required. It is a juvenile outlook on life. Eventually their relationship just drifts apart and dissolves. It's saddening. There is no emotional investment, no arguments. Even arguing indicates interest. But there was none whatsoever. This song is an unusual breakup song in that there is no guilt, anguish, or anger. It is a reflection of her sorrow. This song is a deep sigh from her.
comment_25:
Lana Del Rey, as quoted, when asked bout 'Video Games': "A boy. I think we came together because we were both outsiders. It was perfect. But I think with that contentment also comes sadness. There was something heavenly about that life â we'd go to work and he'd play his video games - but also it was maybe too regular. At the time I was becoming disillusioned with being a singer and was very happy to settle with a boyfriend who I loved, but in the end we both lost sight of our dreams. Maybe there's something not-so-special about domestic life." (thequietus.com/articles/…)

So the song is both happy and sad, a doomed love story that has good memories nonetheless.

(On a side note, this song reminds me of a million ex-boyfriends who would ask me to come over in the evenings after we got home from work or class. I would change out of my day clothes, put on some amazing underwear, try out a new scent, do my hair, pick out an outfit that said casual but sexy, and then drive over to his place only to find him (or him, or him, or him, or the other him, sitting on the couch, playing on PS-whogivesafuck. Men want to play video games for 2-5 hours. Most aren't so brazen to just outright do this, but if I had to guess, this is the ideal situation for like ninety percent of men under the age of thirty-five.

comment_27:
This song, along with many of LDRs songs, is fraught with double meanings. Its good writing, and it leaves the song open to interpretation and the listener can interpret the song to how it best applies to them. This is a very dark song. I think this songs tells a story about a woman who has been abused as a child and grows up to be promiscuous, participating in "video games" aka indecent movies. 

The first two verses, she's describing her father. "Swinging in the backyard" while her father comes home, opens up a beer, calls her over to him, tells her to play a video game? I think "video game" can mean literally or figuratively in this line - or both. I think her father perhaps told her to play a video game to distract her from what he was doing. "I say you the bestest, lean in for a big kiss" - also something a child would say - "bestest". 

"Take that body downtown" - her father telling her to make him some money. 

"Holds me in his big arms, drunk and I am seeing stars" - this line can either refer to her, drunk, and in her lovers arms, or a memory of her in her fathers arms, her father being drunk, and she seeing stars, "seeing stars" usually happening when one is hit in the face. 

The rest of the song is addressed to the man she currently loves. "I heard that you like the bad girls, honey, is that true?" She is a bad girl, and has been for a long time, as is usually the case with a history as described in the song. 

When interpreting the song in these terms, its very sad. This is a recurring theme in some of her songs, like the song "Kinda Outta Luck", in which she describes her father is in the trunk of his brand new car, she wants him back, but "kinda outta luck". 

A previous commenter stated that LDR said "Video games" still makes her cry - which would make sense if you interpret the song in these terms.
comment_28:
What's so great about this song is that juxtaposition of the old and the new. The song feels old, vintage, and continues to feel that way, until you hear the word video games. "What? Video games? Were they even invented back then? Wait - this song was released this year? Seriously?" It's just so mesmerizing. The images of swinging in a back yard while your man pulls up in his "fast car", whistling your name are so old-timey, and then suddenly he's playing video games. It's sort of funny, in a very romantic kind of way.

The way I see it, Lana's not complaining. She's not being snarky when she tells him to "go play a video game". She's enjoying it - just being with him, watching video games. I'm pretty sure Lana said something similiar - that this was a time in her life when she wasn't really focusing on her career or personal ambitions, and was just happy and content to be with her man. For him to come home and play video games. She explicity says this in the song, actually - "this is my idea of fun - playing video games". That is not sarcasm. 

She's just happy to be with her guy, basically. "It's all for you" sort of thing. I think it's a sad song because although it's sung in the present tense, I'm not sure it is for Lana. She loves/loved this guy once, and singing it must be pretty sad. And yeah, she did say it still makes her cry. It makes me cry. It's beautiful, and happy, and sad. The "world is built for two" line is probably the saddest. "Only worth living if somebody is loving you". A lot of people feel they don't, and to hear that is sort of a punch to the gut. 

It's a happy song that evokes a lot of sadness. It's about a past that lives on in the present. Honoring love that has been lost.
comment_29:
I like a lot of what people are saying here. I've been researching opinions and thoughts on her for days now. I find her two tunes "video games" and "born to die" entirely intoxicating. However I dont find any of their immense sadness or eerieness in the album itself though which is a bit lacklustre.
Anyway I think it goes deeper than people have been saying. Postmodern is a problematic term to ascribe but I think in her case it is absolutely appropriate. "Video Games" isn't that she simply watches a man play video games, or that he films her having sex etc Video Games are the symbol or lens with which she view her whole status as a woman and a human being in the 21st century. Everything is playing a part, life is characterised by reproduction of image, cliche and unoriginality, to use Baudrillard's phrase it is a "loss of the real", all is surface, all is texture: she moves, lives, loves in a video. Her collage of american film, film music, american country music, combine with a string of cliches that make up her lyrics "it's all for you" "heaven is a place on earth" "hold me in your big arms" to form an overwhelming, suffocating sense of unreality.

The immense sadness in these two songs isn't so much emotional sadness but is a profound weariness. Much art and music has grown tired and film and video has come so close to life that relationships and emotions can feel just as mechanical. 

She is a huge Kurt Cobain fan apparently. Play the first 10 seconds of Video Games, then first ten seconds of Nirvana's Plateau. The similarity is striking. Both have a similar vibe. Moreover I think the image of the Plateau is a nice way of understanding her world-view in these two songs:  life is surface, controlled, boundrary-defined, static, stagnant and unchanging.

comment_37:
I guess I was overthinking it, but I saw two different messages in the song.

It seems like she's in an unsatisfying relationship with a guy, where she's giving to it more than he is. He's used to her doing everything he wants for him, like dressing and acting a certain way. They've definitely known each other a while, and they have a lot of mutual friends ("watching all our friends fall"). She's getting tired of it, but stays with him, either because she's still attached to him, or she just thinks she doesn't deserve any better. 

A bit more metaphorically, I saw it as a commentary on trying to make it in show business. She has to sell herself, and demean herself by acting out the gender role of the fragile, dependent female in order to move ahead in a vapid industry in a male chauvinistic society.

The lyrics can be suggestively analyzed.  
On the surface, Del rey maybe singing about genuinely pleasing her man, however through the tone of her singing you would quick to pressume she is almost getting impatient with him playing 'video games', however she still quotes that 'I'm in his favorite sun dress' meaning the video games don't matter to her and that the smallest things such as wearing his favourite dress still mean the world to their relationship or her for that matter. 
On a deeper note, if you listen to the levels and tones of the songs you could quite easily anaylse this song on another level. She seems to change her vocals and tones through different verses. Its almost as though she is readdressing the relationship in her head - the bad and the good. Or maybe she is thinking of how it she would like to be with another man - 'Heaven is a place on earth with you
Tell me all the things you want to do

Honey, is that true?'

'I say you the bestest
Lean in for a big kiss
Put his favorite perfume on

Go play a video game'
.. shes eager for his approval and some what a similar reaction back however, when she goes to sing ' go play a video game' the tone of her voice suggests its almost as though she knows deep down he doesnt feel the same, so she pushes it off and doesnt say anything because she loves him and is allowing to let it go without any moaning. This song beautifully captures what so many women are going through, and what I think must be particularly difficult for American women.

The woman â or girl â in this lovely song is infatuated with âhimâ and the world around him, a world she feels lucky to be part of â but regrets sheâs not THE other half of. Sheâs sensing that sheâs on the wrong track, trapped in an image that alienate herself from the people around her, when she really needs those big, loving arms. She tries hard to be the woman he wants her to be, which is consequently the same as hiding her true self. 

Women want to be loved for who/what they are, but Hollywood has created a puppet-factory with guidelines for every woman to follow. These are the measures, this is how your front, your eyes, your lips, your hips, your nails should look like. Sure this dilemma has always existed, also in the 50âies. The 70âies was an exception. Sadly, the modern world has turned its back on most of the important values from his period. And now weâre kind of back to the Stepford wivesâ¦

I love the fact that she calls this song âvideo gamesâ. Being loved is all about being seen â as the person you are. Not the person you are trying to be in order to please somebody. Video is Latin for âI seeâ â and this song is all about the games you play in order to be seen.

She sings âthis is my idea of funâ. Yes! She wants to rebel. Against the people who wants to dictate what she can or cannot do. Only thing is, that even when you feel like youâre fighting the dictators, you very often throw yourself into the arms of new ones â if youâre that kind of person. Hollywood is a nasty dictator.

The tone and tempo gives a feeling of numbness. It describes the feeling of lost love so beautifully. She felt like she was born for this love, this man, so when this is over, everything is over. Youâre dead.

Brr, I have so much to say about this song. But Iâll stop here. comment_69:
I agree with the general consensus that the song is essentially about an insecure woman who is afraid to be alone and is willing to completely refashion herself for a guy, according to what she thinks he wants. I think the guy cheats on her or flirts with other girls, ("I heard you like the bad girls/Honey is that true?") and she gets the idea into her head that those are the kind of girls he likes, so that's whats he has to become.

The second verse, however, is a little bit harder to interpret, but I think it really holds the key to the real meaning of the song. I think it's illustrating how her devotion to this guy has arrested her development. I sort of see her as this small town girl who probably went to high school with him, and they're still doing the same things they've done since they were kids. They and their group of friends were probably the cool, "In" clique at school ("Living for the 'fame'") and that's their only validation so they're holding on to it for dear life. Everyone is afraid of evolving and maturing. Even the title and repeated lyric "Playing video games" brings to mind immaturity and childish pastimes, and their lives ARE a sort of video game; a simulation of real life. This girl can't leave and grow and start a real, fulfilled adult life because she is so focused on making this loser want her, and she's willing to stifle her progression for him.

comment_85:
The song...I feel it's a sad portrait of what many women (and men, for that matter) believe love is, as well as what people are willing to do in order to achieve that often impossible ideal that we like to call 'true love'. 

What people are willing to do...that's where all the implications and undertones of this song come in. It can be interpreted in a wide variety of ways really; maybe she's a girl whose willing to put aside deeper meaning in order to allow herself to fall into a simple, picture perfect world where living life is as simple as picking up a video game and going to a world that's vibrant, fantastic, and blatantly unreal; maybe she's a spurned lover trying to convince herself that her true love did and does in fact love her, and that all she's done up until that point has in fact been successful; or maybe the darkest (and in my mind most likely) interpretation is correct and she IS in fact trapped in that ridiculously familiar cycle of abuse and affection, trying to convince herself that this IS what love is, but realizing that in the end, it's all just a game. 

But no matter what the interpretation, this song is breathtakingly beautiful. It's haunting rendition of love will cloud my mind...well, likely forever at this point.

comment_101:
I first heard this song in a television performance a couple of years ago, and I couldn't get it out of my mind.  I love that it is so enigmatic and subject to so very many interpretations. 

Here is my take on it: 

She is a sweet and innocent young thing, very pretty but weak, impressionable and extremely needy.

I see her as being maybe in her late teens (young enough to be "swinging in the backyard") and the guy is perhaps in his early to mid-20s (old enough to "pull up in your fast car").  Not a big age difference, but significant enough at that time of one's life. 

She is totally infatuated with him, besotted and lovesick.  She will do ANYTHING to please him:  wear his favorite dress, wear his favorite perfume, take her clothes off for him. 

He is completely emotionally uninvolved, however.  He lightheartedly "whistles her name," but in the way that someone would summon a dog.  It's like another way of "snapping his fingers" at her to make her compliant. 

He wants to "take that body downtown" to show off to his friends because while he is EVERYTHING to her, she is nothing more than a pretty face, a plaything for him, a bauble. 

She is obsessed with him.  When they "kiss in the blue dark," or he "holds her in his big arms," she is "drunk [with love] and seeing stars."  But he is just as content to hang out in bars, and play pool and darts....and video games.  When they do this together she says "this is my idea of fun,"  but either 1) she is being sarcastic, or 2) she's willing to try to convince herself she's having fun whenever she's with him, even though she would rather be alone with him than spend time together with his friends. 

She is, basically, a good girl, but willing to be a "bad girl" to please him.  She is being extremely flirtatious [not to mention untrue to herself] when she implies that she will be "bad" if that's what pleases him.  Likewise when she tells him he's the "bestest." 

They way she croons "it's you, it's you, it's all for you," I can't help but think of someone who would go as far as suicide if the object of her obsession were to leave her. 

Like many of the comments here will agree, this is a very dark, very melancholy song; and the tone of voice in which it's sung is perfectly fitting.

comment_104:
I very recently stumbled upon Lana Del Rey. Shortly after that I discovered she's a recovering alcoholic who said herself that when she's talking about a love in her life she's probably referring to her "first love; alcohol." As an alcoholic struggling to get sober her music gives me peace. This song, for me, is yet another interpretation of her struggled love affair with alcohol.

The first verse feels like an association to when she was first introduced to alcohol. Maybe it was a boy that would 'pull up in a fast car whistling (her) name' but I also see it as that exhilarating feeling  of alcohol as the drunkenness creeps in, calling for her to have a drink. 'Video games' is a reference to a life that's not real. Because life as an alcoholic is a life not really lived or experienced, no matter how much we convince ourselves its reality. 

The next couple of lines remind me of sex when you're drunk. Its fun. Its sexy. Still not real. The 'Favorite perfume' will always be the smell of alcohol on someone's breath.

The chorus is most important. Its her love song to alcohol. 
"It's you, it's you, it's all for you
 Everything I do
 I tell you all the time
 Heaven is a place on earth with you" 
If you're an alcoholic, this makes perfect sense. There is nothing that feels better than being drunk. Its a sweet release.
"Tell me all the things you want to do"
 When you're drunk you have high aspirations, most of which will never play out as long as you're not recovering. 
"I heard that you like the bad girls honey, is that true?"
Bad girls are drunk girls. Alcoholic women live to test boundaries. They live to be sluts. They love to be vulgar. They love attention. They being me!
The last stanza is about giving yourself completely over to alcohol. 
 "It's better than I ever even knew
 They say that the world was built for two
 Only worth living if somebody is loving you
 Baby now you do (Now you do)"
Nothing feels better than alcohol. And it can easily take the place of real human interaction. The alcoholic doesn't need anything but the bottle and their imagination. No need to worry if someone else will love you if you know alcohol will.

The second verse plays out a typical drunk night. They're all the same. 'Playing pool and wild darts'. 'Seeing stars' is all she thinks of now. Watching friends do the same drunken thin every night is her 'idea of fun'

And then back to the chorus.

comment_111:
It could just be a straight-up song about an actual relationship. But here's my take:

Video games are fine, in moderation. But compulsive gamers use video games as a substitute for real life. They become content to control the images they see on the screen. 

Same thing happens with sexuality. Getting too caught up in popular sexual ideals can lead to objectification. Usually this means hotness becomes the ultimate goal. People will watch crappy movies, so long as the actors are hot. People will listen to crappy music, so long as the singer is hot. Del Reyâs critics have slammed her for pandering to this type of consumer.

These lyrics seem too self-aware for Del Rey to actually be the pathetic woman in this song. And as an artist, she hasnât toned down her sexy image, at all. So âitâs all for youâ seems to be a sarcastic acknowledgement of her critics. She implies that the problem is with the consumer who chooses to ignore her music & focus on her sexuality, including those who demand that she tone down the sex.
